channel.title: TU Computer Science and Engineering
channel.description: Recent content on TU Computer Science and Engineering

item.title: Computer Science as a Career
item.description: Why work in Computer Science?

item.title: Info
item.description: For Prospective Students Looking to find the Computer Science department that’s right for you? Find out more about Computer Science as a career See our degrees at a glance with sample 4 year plans Find out about our curriculum Have your frequently asked questions answered See what cool clubs and activities our students participate in Additional links Meet some of our current students, alumni, or our faculty

item.title: Degrees at a Glance
item.description: Please note, these are intended to be samples only, your 4 year plan will look a bit different depending on the classes you choose, and when you take them Computer Science        Bachelor of Arts in Computer Science        Bachelor of Science in Computer Science        Bachelor of Science in Computer Science with Systems Curriculum Computer Science Digital Media        Bachelor of Arts in Computer Science - Digital Media

item.title: Alumni
item.description: Grant Hollis Grant Hollis works at Lockheed Martin Grant Hollis graduated from Taylor in 2004 with a Bachelors of Science in Computer Science, Systems, a concentration on Intelligent Systems, and a minor in Theater Arts. While at Taylor, Grant learned how to define goals, organize himself to create a solid route to completion, communicate that to others, and celebrate upon achievement. Grant greatly values how Taylor’s education prepared him for the workplace: “It serves as the foundation for my career.

item.title: Meet Our Students
item.description: Courtney Masters Courtney is a Sophomore studying Digital Media Courtney Masters is a Sophomore studying Computer Science - Digital Media B.A. She is currently most interested in a career in web development or software engineering after she graduates in 2022. Courtney heard about Taylor’s Computer Science department from her older brother and other friends. “I was particularly attracted to the digital media program because it incorporated design and film along with programming.

item.title: First Year Projects
item.description: Whose AI will win? In their first year, Computer Science students will take both COS 120, and COS 121, which teaches students to code from square one. Regardless of the experience students come in with, they will be given the foundational skills necessary code their own AIs (artificial intelligence) to play games, like Checkers, Risk, and Battleships. COS 120, Introduction to Computational Problem Solving, teaches students essential coding principles, and gives them their first taste solving real world computational problems using Python.

item.title: Links
item.description: As a student, you have free access to the complete suite of developer tools by JetBrains. Find out more here. To activate Azure for students to get access to a suite of services to help you develop and deploy enterprise-grade web apps, among other things, sign in to your Taylor account here.

item.title: Poster Printing Services
item.description: THIS IS NOT THE TAYLOR PRINT SHOP. We cannot accept the discount coupons/forms that they provide. Please contact the University Press at x85218 or visit them (by the TU Post Office) if you have a coupon and need a poster printed. The CSE Dept is happy to provide large format printing for our students. We can print up to 42” wide by any length. New for 2017: We are using semi-gloss coated paper, which makes your prints look much nicer.

item.title: FAQ
item.description: FAQ How can I transfer my AP or dual credit classes? What’s a double major? Double majors are for people who are interested in studying more than one major. Taylor University allows students to declare any combination of minors and majors. Be sure that there is adequate overlap between the two majors so that you can finish in time! Also, be aware that there is a 160 credit hour cap.

item.title: GameJam
item.description: The TU CSE GameJam is a game jam series hosted every semester by the CSE Department and Dr. Jon Denning and run by students at Taylor University. A game jam is a short, fun, and intense party during which students get together to develop a video game from scratch. Regardless of major or knowledge of programming, all TU students are invited to participate!

item.title: Dr. Dannie Stanley
item.description: Associate Professor When I set out to become a professor in 2004, I identified Taylor University specifically as the place that I would like to teach. I did not realize at the time how unlikely it was that I would actually get to work at my first choice (but here I sit). Though I was not a student at Taylor, I grew up in nearby Van Buren and was surrounded by community members involved with Taylor.

item.title: Dr. Jeff Cramer
item.description: Associate Professor As an elementary education major at Taylor University, I always thought I would someday like to be a professor. I never thought I would return to Taylor viaÂ the Computer Science and Engineering department!   After teaching in a public school in Indianapolis for six years, I decided to go back to graduate school. While working on my M.S. degree in Instructional Systems Technology at Indiana University, I realized how much I liked learning about the appropriate uses of technology in anÂ educational setting.

item.title: Dr. Jon Denning
item.description: Assistant Professor and Department Co-chair In fall 2014, I started as an assistant professor teaching computer graphics and core Computer Science courses. I find graphics fascinating because it creatively combines many disciplinesâphysics, math, data structures, and artâand produces images that are simple, yet awe-inspiring and rich with details.   The past few years have been a whirlwind of excitement for and blessings on my family, and looking back itâs obvious that God has led us to where we are now.

item.title: Dr. Jonathan Geisler
item.description: Associate Professor What can I say thatâs enlightening? Iâm not as funny as Dr. Brandle, so I think Iâll just be plain and tell you a bit about myself.   Iâm a Taylor Computer Science and Engineering grad (Dec. â94), so Iâve been involved in the department since 1991. I took a couple years off to work at Argonne National Laboratory before attending Northwestern University for my PhD.

item.title: Dr. Stefan Brandle
Dr. Tom Nurkkala
item.description: Associate Professor Iâm at Taylor because I want to help train and mentor excellent computer scientists and engineers who are also dedicated followers of Christ. In addition, as a member of the Center for Missions Computing, I want to leverage the intellectual horsepower and spiritual maturity of the students at Taylor to help solve practical computing problems for the global mission community.   To accomplish these goals, I plan to employ my educational and industrial experience.

item.title: Systems Option
item.description: What is Systems? Systems is not a minor in ComputerÂ Science. The goal of the Systems curriculum is to help students recognize that the world is filled with systems (like educational, distribution, and manufacturing systems). It is the processes inhabiting these systems that produce value and help organizations achieve high performance. Our graduates are enjoying careers at enterprises of all sizes, including global consulting companies.   What in the world is Accenture selling?

item.title: Abet Accreditation
item.description: Our Engineering & Computer Engineering programs are ABET-accredited. Accreditation The Engineering & Computer Engineering degree programs are accredited by the Engineering Accreditation Commission of ABET (https://www.abet.org). Program Educational Objectives Prepare our graduates to server others dependably, most importantly their employer, customers, and community. Prepare our graduates to practice technical competence, producing reliable engineering designs. Prepare our graduates to exercise creativity in their work, fostering innovative solutions.

item.title: About Us
item.description: Sometimes alumni Ashley Crutcher designs websites that convince people to buy products, like guacamole. But sometimes her goal is more serious, like convincing people to follow Jesus. At Taylor University, the Computer Science & Engineering (CSE) department is more than just a section of the science building. We have our own community on the second floor of the environmentally sustainableÂ Euler Science Complex that flourishes as a learning environment.

item.title: Faculty
item.description: Faculty and Staff The Computer Science and Engineering faculty and staff are a group of highly qualified professionals with expertise and experiences that include software engineering, artificial intelligence, leadership in major corporations, ethics in technology, and computing standards in tax codes. They each value interaction with students both inside and outside of the classroom. The faculty and staff care about the students as mentors and friends. Their conversations can range anywhere from the classic Star Wars/Star Trek/Avengers talk to deep theology or philosophy.

item.title: Taylor Satellite (TSAT)
item.description: Taylor to the skies TSAT launching from Cape Canaveral (Photo courtesy of NASA.) The Taylor Satellite (TSAT) is a student-developed dual Cube-Sat Unit (4 x 4 x 8 inches) nanosatellite participating in NASAâs ELANA-5 (Educational Launch of Nanosatellites). TSAT was selected by NASA in a competitive program with other universities and was the only undergraduate program chosen. TSAT is short for Taylor, Technology, and TEST â Satellite.

item.title: Tweet
item.description: TWEET Meeting for Brunch Also known as Taylor Women Engaging in Engineering and Technology, this club allows women in Taylorâs science, technology, engineering, and math (STEM) to participate in fun activities together. They also work to promote STEM to young girls in the Upland community . TWEETâs mission is to provide a community that encourages and unites women in a field where they are are significantly outnumbered.

item.title: Organizations and Activities in CSE
item.description: Activities in CSE Clubs TWEET Also known as Taylor Women Engaging in Engineering and Technology, this club allows women in Taylor’s science, technology, engineering, and math (STEM) to participate in fun activities together. They also work to promote STEM to young girls in the Upland community . TWEET’s mission is to provide a community that encourages and unites women in a field where they are are significantly outnumbered.

item.title: Taylor Sends ThinSat to Space
item.description: Ported from an Echo article by Ellie Tiemens Computer science and engineering students made Taylor history with the launch of their nanosatellite. Photo by Ryan Jones Taylor University students and faculty recently partnered with NearSpace Launch Inc. to make history in sending nanosatellites to space. On April 17 at 4:46 p.m., computer science students, engineering students and faculty watched as nearly two years their of hard work was launched into space.

item.title: CERIAS Security Symposium
item.description: By: Dannie M. Stanley Sat, Apr 7, 2018 Ported from CyberSecurity Site This week eight students ventured with me to Purdue University in West Lafayette, IN, to attend the 19th annual CERIAS Security Symposium. As a graduate student at Purdue I was heavily involved with CERIAS, so the trip was both highly relevant to our students and a good chance for me to reconnect with cybersecurity colleagues. Symposium presenters and panelists are cybersecurity experts from academia, industry, and government.

item.title: Lockheed Martin Grant Extended for Further Malware Research
item.description: Reposted from Taylor University Site Aerospace and defense industry company Lockheed Martin has granted a $75,000 renewal of a grant to the Taylor University Computer Science (CSE) Department as part of a multi-year partnership to create cybersecurity solutions. The grant comes a little more than a year after the preliminary $100,000 grant from Lockheed Martin Advanced Technology Labs for research work done in 2017. According to Taylor faculty members, a number of Taylor CSE students and faculty worked on the project during the 2017 spring and fall semesters, and also during the summer.

item.title: Feature Selection for Malware Classification
item.description: Feature Selection for Malware Classification Mitchell Mays Noah Drabinsky Dr. Stefan Brandle Fri, Apr 28, 2017 In applying machine learning to malware identification, different types of features have proven to be successful. These features have also been tested with different kinds of classification methodologies and have had varying degrees of success. Every time a new machine learning methodology is introduced for classifying malware, there is the potential for increasing the overall quality of malware classification in the field.

item.title: Improved User Security Through Graphical Feedback
item.description: Improved User Security Through Graphical Feedback Justice Juraschek Dannie M. Stanley Wed, Jul 27, 2016 A plethora of methods of being secure are available to end-users. However, there is a lack of adoption of those methods. We argue that one of the primary reasons for this is the absence of proper feedback within security-sensitive situations. We believe that a graphical representation of security-related consequences can positively influence security-sensitive user decisions.

item.title: Improved Kernel Security Through Memory Layout Randomization
item.description: Improved Kernel Security Through Memory Layout Randomization Dannie M. Stanley Dongyan Xu Eugene H. Spafford Fri, Dec 6, 2013 The vast majority of hosts on the Internet, including mobile clients, are running on one of three major operating system families. Malicious operating system kernel software, such as the code introduced by a kernel rootkit, is strongly dependent on the organization of the victim operating system. Due to the lack of diversity of operating systems, attackers can craft a single kernel exploit that has the potential to infect millions of hosts.
